title: Implement Queue
description:
Implement Queue

Implement a queue data structure with the following operations:

  • enqueue(val): Add an element to the end of the queue
  • dequeue(): Remove and return the front element from the queue
  • front(): Return the front element without removing it
  • empty(): Return whether the queue is empty

You can choose to implement the queue using either:

  • Linked List - Each node points to the next node
  • Circular Array - Fixed-size array with wrapping

Examples:

  • Input: ["Queue", "enqueue", "enqueue", "front", "dequeue", "empty"]
    [[], [1], [2], [], [], []]
    Output: [null, null, null, 1, 1, false]
  • Input: ["Queue", "enqueue", "dequeue", "empty"]
    [[], [10], [], []]
    Output: [null, null, 10, true]

Constraints:

  • 1 <= val <= 10^9
  • At most 10^4 calls will be made to each function
  • dequeue and front will only be called on non-empty queues
solution_text:
Implement Queue

Algorithm (Linked List Approach):

  1. Use a singly linked list where each node contains a value and pointer to next
  2. Maintain both head (front) and tail (rear) pointers
  3. Enqueue: Add new node at tail
  4. Dequeue: Remove head and return its value
  5. Front: Return head value without removal
  6. Empty: Check if head is None

Algorithm (Circular Array Approach):

  1. Use a fixed-size array with front and rear indices
  2. Enqueue: Add element at rear index and increment rear (with wrap-around)
  3. Dequeue: Remove element at front index and increment front (with wrap-around)
  4. Front: Return element at front index
  5. Empty: Check if front equals rear when queue is empty

Time Complexity: O(1) for all operations

Space Complexity: O(n) where n is number of elements

Key Insights:

  • Linked list approach is simpler and doesn't need fixed capacity
  • Circular array is more memory efficient but requires capacity management
  • Both approaches provide O(1) operations
  • Queue follows FIFO (First In First Out) principle
